question_text: Why do fermentable substrates like glucose yield lower anodic Coulombic efficiencies (ACE) compared to non-fermentable substrates like acetate in microbial fuel cells, and how does syntrophic metabolism improve overall energy recovery?
standard_answer: Fermentable substrates such as glucose exhibit lower ACE due to electron diversion into multiple parallel metabolic pathways beyond exoelectrogenesis. Glucose degradation involves fermentation producing volatile fatty acids, alcohols, and H2, which consume electrons for biomass synthesis and maintenance, reducing the fraction harvested as current. For example, glucose-fed MFCs achieved ACE ~49%, with 26% electrons lost to biomass, 18% to residual organics, and 3.7% to CH4. In contrast, acetate, a non-fermentable substrate, supports direct oxidation by exoelectrogens like Geobacter, yielding ACE up to 71% with lower losses (15% biomass, 11% residuals). Thermodynamically, direct glucose oxidation liberates -2176.7 kJ/mol, but only 54% is recovered as electricity via DET due to high biological energy dissipation. Syntrophic metabolism improves energy recovery by coupling fermentation and exoelectrogenesis: glucose fermentation to acetate and H2 (Reaction 2a) followed by oxidation of these intermediates. H2 oxidation abiotically yields -179.5 kJ/mol, and acetate oxidation via DET gives -393.7 kJ/mol, totaling 1505.4 kJ/mol from 1 mol glucoseâ€”a 69% energy efficiency. This synergy allows specialized microbes (fermenters and exoelectrogens) to optimize electron flow, minimizing losses and enhancing overall system performance.

original_text.1: When the BES is fed with fermentable substrates, fermentation is also involved in microbial metabolism. Therefore, fermentable substances suffer from more severe electron losses to undesirable processes compared to nonfermentable ones.
original_text.2: In comparison, a much higher ACE of 71% was obtained by the acetate-fed MFC, because cell synthesis and residual organic compounds accounted for only 15% and 11% of the total electrons extracted from acetate.
